page.title: 18TYWARDREATH- 19TH CENTURY
page.content: In {Tywardreath in the 1840's}life was very poor. The main industry was {mining tin and copper.} There are still old engine houses around. The population of the village was 3000 to 4000 people. A large number worked at {Fowey Consols}copper mine. The women and girls broke up the ore when it came from the mine. They were paid 40p a week. The mines were all lit by candles and until 1851 the miners had to climb long ladders at the beginning and end of every day. Girls as young as 7 or 8 worked for 3d a day. No women, girls or boys under 10 worked underground. The men were paid half in money and half in tokens. The tokens had to be spent in the mine owners' shops and pubs. Most houses belonged to the mine owners. Two cottages in North Street were built from mine waste.
